children.value: In this section we will examine the disassembly of a simple C program that multiplies two integers. The program is compiled for the i386 architecture, which is a 32-bit architecture commonly used in older computers and embedded systems. The disassembly will help us understand how the C code translates into assembly instructions, and how these instructions are executed by the CPU.
Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.label: Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.value: The C program is compiled using the GCC compiler with the
flag to specify the i386 architecture. The
flag creates assembly code in the Intel format. The
flag includes C source code in the assembly code, and the
flag compiles the assembly code into an object file.

gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -masm=intel -S -fverbose-asm mult_int.c -o mult_int.s
gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -c mult_int.s -o mult_int.o
The assembly code is in Intel syntax, which is commonly used for x86 assembly language.

.file	"mult_int.c"
	.intel_syntax noprefix
# GNU C17 (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) version 14.2.0 (x86_64-conda-linux-gnu)
#	compiled by GNU C version 14.2.0, GMP version 6.2.1, MPFR version 4.1.0, MPC version 1.2.1, isl version isl-0.24-GMP

# GGC heuristics: --param ggc-min-expand=100 --param ggc-min-heapsize=131072
# options passed: -m32 -masm=intel -mtune=generic -march=x86-64
	.text
	.globl	main
	.type	main, @function
main:
.LFB0:
	.cfi_startproc
	push	ebp	#
	.cfi_def_cfa_offset 8
	.cfi_offset 5, -8
	mov	ebp, esp	#,
	.cfi_def_cfa_register 5
	sub	esp, 16	#,
	call	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax	#
	add	eax, OFFSET FLAT:_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_	# tmp98,
# mult_int.c:7: 	a = 2;
	mov	DWORD PTR -4[ebp], 2	# a,
# mult_int.c:8: 	b = 3;
	mov	DWORD PTR -8[ebp], 3	# b,
# mult_int.c:10: 	c = a * b;
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR -4[ebp]	# tmp102, a
	imul	eax, DWORD PTR -8[ebp]	# c_3, b
	mov	DWORD PTR -12[ebp], eax	# c, c_3
	mov	eax, 0	# _4,
# mult_int.c:11: }
	leave	
	.cfi_restore 5
	.cfi_def_cfa 4, 4
	ret	
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE0:
	.size	main, .-main
	.section	.text.__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,"axG",@progbits,__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,comdat
	.globl	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.hidden	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.type	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax, @function
__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax:
.LFB1:
	.cfi_startproc
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR [esp]	#,
	ret
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE1:
	.ident	"GCC: (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) 14.2.0"
	.section	.note.GNU-stack,"",@progbits
The attached code is an assembly file (
) generated from a simple C program (
) that performs integer multiplication. It is written in Intel syntax and compiled for a 32-bit architecture (
) using GCC 14.2.0. Below is a detailed explanation of the code:
: Indicates that this assembly code was generated from the C source file
: Specifies that the assembly code uses Intel syntax (as opposed to AT&T syntax).
: Marks the beginning of the code (text) section where executable instructions are stored.
function as global, making it accessible to the linker.
: A local label used internally by the assembler for debugging purposes.
: Marks the start of the Call Frame Information (CFI) for the function, used for stack unwinding during debugging.

push	ebp	#
	.cfi_def_cfa_offset 8
	.cfi_offset 5, -8
	mov	ebp, esp	#,
	.cfi_def_cfa_register 5
	sub	esp, 16	#,
) of the previous stack frame onto the stack.
) to the value of the stack pointer (
: Allocates 16 bytes of space on the stack for local variables.

call	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax	#
	add	eax, OFFSET FLAT:_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_	# tmp98,
: Calls a helper function to get the program counter (PC) value.
: Adjusts the PC value to point to the Global Offset Table (GOT), which is used for position-independent code.

# mult_int.c:10: 	c = a * b;
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR -4[ebp]	# tmp102, a
	imul	eax, DWORD PTR -8[ebp]	# c_3, b
	mov	DWORD PTR -12[ebp], eax	# c, c_3
: Stores the result of the multiplication (
: Sets the return value of the
: Restores the previous stack frame by setting
This function retrieves the program counter (PC) value and stores it in the
register. It is used for position-independent code to calculate addresses relative to the GOT.
: Contains metadata about the compiler version used.
: Marks the stack as non-executable for security purposes.
This assembly code implements a simple C program that multiplies two integers (
) and stores the result in a variable (
function sets up the stack frame, performs the multiplication using the
as the exit status. The helper function
The object file is linked to create an executable file using the
The executable file is disassembled using the

objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel mult_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel mult_int_C_i386 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt

The attached file is the output of the
command applied to an object file (
). It provides a detailed view of the binary structure, including sections, symbols, and disassembled machine code. Below is a detailed explanation of the key parts of the file:

mult_int.o:     file format elf32-i386
architecture: i386, flags 0x00000011:
HAS_RELOC, HAS_SYMS
start address 0x00000000
: The object file is in the ELF (Executable and Linkable Format) for a 32-bit Intel architecture (
: The code is compiled for the i386 architecture (32-bit x86).
: The file contains relocation entries, which are used to adjust addresses during linking.
: The file contains a symbol table.
: The entry point of the object file is at address
The object file is divided into sections, each serving a specific purpose. Below are the key sections:
